Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the statement that over R1.3 trillion has been invested in infrastructure over the past five years.
Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the progress made in infrastructure provision by stating that hundreds of thousands of new homes have been built, without providing specific evidence or numbers.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the investment in infrastructure has resulted in significant progress, without providing concrete evidence or indicators of progress.
Understate: The claim may be understating the actual progress in infrastructure provision by not mentioning any specific achievements or outcomes.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the progress in infrastructure provision, such as the contribution of foreign direct investment or other factors, which are not mentioned in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that South Africa is ranked 82 out of 190 countries in terms of ease of doing business, as reported by the World Bank. This contradicts the claim of significant progress in infrastructure provision.
